review.title: Mining Process Model Descriptions of Daily Life through Event Abstraction
review.abstract: Process mining techniques focus on extracting insight in processes from event logs. Process mining has the potential to provide valuable insights in (un)healthy habits and to contribute to ambient assisted living solutions when applied on data from smart home environments. However, events recorded in smart home environments are on the level of sensor triggers, at which process discovery algorithms produce overgeneralizing process models that allow for too much behavior and that are difficult to interpret for human experts. We show that abstracting the events to a higher-level interpretation can enable discovery of more precise and more comprehensible models. We present a framework for the extraction of features that can be used for abstraction with supervised learning methods that is based on the XES IEEE standard for event logs. This framework can automatically abstract sensor-level events to their interpretation at the human activity level, after training it on training data for which both the sensor and human activity events are known. We demonstrate our abstraction framework on three real-life smart home event logs and show that the process models that can be discovered after abstraction are more precise indeed.
histories: arXiv admin note: substantial text overlap witharXiv:1606.07283
review.COMMENTS: arXiv admin note: substantial text overlap witharXiv:1606.07283
authors: wil m p van der aalst

sections.text: ar Xiv: 170 5.10 202v 1 [cs.L G] 25 Mevent logs P. Process Mining has the potential to provide valuable insights into (un) healthy habits and contribute to solutions for ambient life when applied to data from smart home environments. However, events recorded in smart home environments are at the level of sensor triggers, where process recognition algorithms produce over-generalizing process models that allow too much behavior and are difficult for human experts to interpret. We show that the abstraction of events can lead to a superior interpretation that can enable the discovery of more precise and comprehensible models. We present a framework for the extraction of features that can be used for abstraction with supervised learning methods methods methods based on the XES IEEE standard for event logs. This framework can automatically abstract events at the human activity level to their interpretation.

sections.heading: 3 Preliminaries
sections.text: In this section we present basic concepts and notation used throughout the paper. We use the standard sequence definition and designate a sequence by listing its elements, e.g. we write < a1, a2,.., an > for a (finite) sequence s: {1,.., n} → S of elements from any alphabet S, where s (i) = ai stands for any i sequence {1,.., n}.

sections.text: In fact, the majority of them are able to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to move, to move, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to fight, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move, to move.

sections.heading: 3.2 Conditional Random Field
sections.text: We consider the detection of events at the human activity level to be a sequence marking task, in which each sensor-level event is divided into one of the events at the human activity level. Linear-chain Conditional Random Fields (CRFs) [17] are a kind of probabilistic graphical model that has proven successful in many sequence marking tasks in the areas of language processing and computer vision. Conceptually, CRFs can be considered a sequential version of the logistic regression of several classes, i.e., the predictions in the prediction sequence are interdependent. A CRF models the conditional probability distribution of the sequence using a loglinear model. Linear chain CRFs take the following form: p (y | x) = 1Z (x) exp (∑ t = 1 ∑ k fk (t, yt, x)))) (1), with Z (x) being the normalization factor < < the probability that the CRF is < < < the probability of the events is < < < the probability of the value of the CRF; < < < < < < < < < < < = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = = =

sections.heading: 4 Motivating Example
sections.text: Figure 1 shows a simplistic example of how a process at the sensor level of events can appear unstructured while structured at the human behavioral level. Petrinetz 1c shows the process at the human activity level. Human activity level is itself defined as a process represented in Figures 1a to 1c. Food is also defined as a process represented in Figure 1b. Applying the algorithm for the discovery of inductive mining [18] to traces generated by the hierarchical process of Figure 1c at the sensor level, we obtain the process model shown in Figure 1d. This process model enables almost all possible sequences via the alphabet {CD, D, DCC, MC, W}, whereby the only restriction introduced by the model is that if a W occurs, the process model must be driven by a DCC event.

sections.text: In fact, it is the case that most of them will be able to move into a different world, in which they are able to move, in which they are able to move, in which they are able to live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they, in which they live, in which they, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live.

sections.heading: 5.2 Evaluating Human Activity Level Event Predictions for Process Mining Applications
sections.text: Existing approaches to activity detection are based on time frames in which each time frame is represented by a feature vector that describes sensor activity or status during that time frame. So there are two reasons to deviate from this evaluation method in a process mining setting: First, our method works on events rather than on time frames. Second, the accuracy of the resulting high-level sequences is much more important for many process techniques (e.g. process finding, conformity verification) than the accuracy of predicting each minute of the day. A known metric for the distance of two sequences is the Levenshtein distance [19]. However, Levenshtein distance is not suitable for comparing sequences of human actions, as human behavior sometimes includes branches in which it does not matter in which order two activities are performed.

sections.heading: 6 Case Studies
sections.text: In this section, we evaluate the supervised event abstraction framework based on three case studies of real smart home datasets.

sections.heading: 6.1 Experimental setup
sections.text: We include three smart home event logs in the evaluation: the Van Kasteren Event Log [14], and two event logs from a smart home experiment by MIT [30]. All three event logs used for the evaluation consist of multi-dimensional time series data with all dimensions binary, each binary dimension representing the state of an in-home sensor. These sensors include motion sensors, open / close sensors, and power sensors (discredited to 0 / 1 states). We transform the multi-dimensional time series data relating to each sensor change point as an event. Cases are generated by grouping events that occurred on the same day, with a cut-off point provided for event recording. The following XES extensions can be used for these events.

sections.heading: 6.2 Case Study 1: Van Kasteren Event Log
sections.text: For the first case study, we use the Smart Home Environment Log described in Van Kasteren et al. [14] The Van Kasteren Log contains 1285 events, divided into fourteen different sensors, and the log contains 23 days of data.The average Damerau-Levenshtein similarity between the predicted traces of human activity in the Leave-One-Trace-Out-Cross-Validation experiment and the traces of human activity on the ground is 0.7516, showing that the monitored event method produces traces that match the ground probability.Figure 5 shows the result of the inductive miner [18] for the sensory events in the Van Kasteren dataset. The resulting process model starts with a choice of four activities: hall door, hallway-bedroom door, hallway-bathroom door and front door. After this choice, the model branches out into three parallel blocks, in which the upper block of a selection of eight different types of each of activities is very similar to the other paralleled one.

sections.heading: 6.3 Case Study 2: MIT Household A Event Log
sections.text: For the second case study, we use household A data from a smart home experiment conducted by MIT [30]. However, household A contains data on 16 days of life, 2701 sensor-level events recorded by 26 different sensors. Human-level activities are provided in the form of a taxonomy of activities at three levels, which are called heading, category and sub-category. At the transmission level, human activities are very general, such as personal needs. At the sub-category level, the eight different activities at the transmission level are divided into 19 different category-level activities, where personal needs branch out, for example, into eating, sleeping and personal hygiene. At the sub-category level, there are more types of human activities than sensor activities, which include very specific human activities. At the sub-category level, cleaning meals, for example, is divided into dishes and discarding dishes.

sections.heading: 6.4 Case Study 3: MIT Household B Event Log
sections.text: For the third case study, we use data from household B of the MIT Smart Home experiment [30]. Household B contains data on 17 days of life, 1962 sensor-based events recorded by 20 different sensors. Identical to MIT Household A, human-level activities are provided as a three-step taxonomy. Here, too, we use the subcategory level of this taxonomy as a target activity label. The model discovered with the Inductive Miner [18] from sensor-level events is Figure 9. The model obtained allows too much behavior as it contains two large selection blocks. We found a Damerau-Levenshtein similarity of 0.5865 in the Leave-One-Trace-Out-Cross Validation experiment, which is lower than the similarity found on the MIT A dataset, while the abstraction target classes for the two datasets are the same. This can be explained by the fact that there is less behavioral data for this part of the 1932-year budget, which contains only non-specific training events B.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we presented a framework for abstract events implemented within the framework of the ProM Process Mining Toolkit. An important part of the framework is a generic method to extract useful abstraction features from the extensions to event logs defined in the XES IEEE standard. We propose the Damerau-Levenshtein Similarity to evaluate abstraction results and explain why it fits the application of Process Mining. Finally, using three real smart home datasets, we demonstrated that the application of the supervised event abstraction framework allows us to create more precise process model descriptions of human life compared to those that could be derived from the original data at the sensor level. Furthermore, these process models contain interpretable event labels at the level of human behavioral activity.

referenceMentions.context: Process mining is a fast growing discipline that combines methods from computational intelligence, data mining, process modeling and process analysis [1].

There are many different process discovery algorithms ([2, 7, 37, 36, 18]), which can discover many different types of process models, including BPMN models, Petri nets, process trees, UML activity diagrams, and statecharts.

While originally the scope of process mining has been on business processes, it has broadened in recent years towards other application areas, including the analysis of human behavior [29, 31, 32].

Additionally, simply using the sensor that generated the event as the event label has been shown to result in non-informative process models that overgeneralize the event log and allow for too much behavior [34].

In our earlier work [31] we showed how to discover more precise process models by taking the name of the sensor as a starting point for the event label and then refine the labels using the time of the day at which the event occurred.
In this paper we extend the work started in [33].

Most related work for abstracting from sensor-level to human activity level events can be found in the field of activity recognition, which focuses on the task of detecting different types of human activity from either passive sensors [14, 30], wearable sensors [3, 16], or cameras [22].

metadata.abstractText: Process mining techniques focus on extracting insight in processes from event logs. Process mining has the potential to provide valuable insights in (un)healthy habits and to contribute to ambient assisted living solutions when applied on data from smart home environments. However, events recorded in smart home environments are on the level of sensor triggers, at which process discovery algorithms produce overgeneralizing process models that allow for too much behavior and that are difficult to interpret for human experts. We show that abstracting the events to a higher-level interpretation can enable discovery of more precise and more comprehensible models. We present a framework for the extraction of features that can be used for abstraction with supervised learning methods that is based on the XES IEEE standard for event logs. This framework can automatically abstract sensorlevel events to their interpretation at the human activity level, after training it on training data for which both the sensor and human activity events are known. We demonstrate our abstraction framework on three real-life smart home event logs and show that the process models that can be discovered after abstraction are more precise indeed.
